        <span key="72e54edfd2be4922833f622474264a4c"><span offset-key="72e54edfd2be4922833f622474264a4c:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://www.gatsbyjs.com/docs/conceptual/graphql-concepts/#getting-started-with-graphql" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="7a92fc1f96314774a8fbd61645048507" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-8575_259-8576-237__"><span data-key="6d2ac16d07784832a713a457fa0d621b"><span data-offset-key="6d2ac16d07784832a713a457fa0d621b:0">Getting started with GraphQL</span></span></span></a><span key="4ac2f90de173454db4bb2650e7402197"><span offset-key="4ac2f90de173454db4bb2650e7402197:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

    -   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

        <span key="4667fd6592d14daaa55d893031b620bf"><span offset-key="4667fd6592d14daaa55d893031b620bf:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://www.gatsbyjs.com/docs/conceptual/graphql-concepts/#advanced-readings-on-graphql" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="c9b7d8f6511e4dfea4bc3eb1273de16f" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-8575_259-8576-237__"><span data-key="3ef54a4343f1477fafd0f0789333e17e"><span data-offset-key="3ef54a4343f1477fafd0f0789333e17e:0">Advanced readings on GraphQL</span></span></span></a><span key="91ac49ac130044a39360b8e067468c8b"><span offset-key="91ac49ac130044a39360b8e067468c8b:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

<span key="45bea1a683cd416cb79a93d5ff23967f"><span offset-key="45bea1a683cd416cb79a93d5ff23967f:0">There are many options for loading data into React components. One of the most popular and powerful of these is a technology called </span></span><a href="https://graphql.org" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="f23fdb09391f47b191945f9bfa1eba3b" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-8575_259-8576-237__"><span data-key="5db49122d1a44dcf923c493a0cf49e77"><span data-offset-key="5db49122d1a44dcf923c493a0cf49e77:0">GraphQL</span></span></span></a><span key="27be0e8fde7848da90d425dfa5cb9c73"><span offset-key="27be0e8fde7848da90d425dfa5cb9c73:0">.</span></span>

<span key="7832e938f4d345dd91e8c2ab119ce1a2"><span offset-key="7832e938f4d345dd91e8c2ab119ce1a2:0">GraphQL was invented at Facebook to help product engineers </span>*pull*<span offset-key="7832e938f4d345dd91e8c2ab119ce1a2:2"> needed data into React components.</span></span>

<span key="6f8ec0a7a6f041ba88d3572533f4b11a"><span offset-key="6f8ec0a7a6f041ba88d3572533f4b11a:0">GraphQL is a </span>**q**<span offset-key="6f8ec0a7a6f041ba88d3572533f4b11a:2">uery </span>**l**<span offset-key="6f8ec0a7a6f041ba88d3572533f4b11a:4">anguage (the </span>*QL*<span offset-key="6f8ec0a7a6f041ba88d3572533f4b11a:6"> part of its name). If you’re familiar with SQL, it works in a very similar way. Using a special syntax, you describe the data you want in your component and then that data is given to you.</span></span>

<span key="adaa0c5bc40a4db8b178aa72be079f32"><span offset-key="adaa0c5bc40a4db8b178aa72be079f32:0">Gatsby uses GraphQL to enable </span></span><a href="https://www.gatsbyjs.com/docs/conceptual/building-with-components/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="a82d15fec77e444ea0272765c1aeae9f" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-8575_259-8576-237__"><span data-key="93d53297964b4528a16201590d0612a9"><span data-offset-key="93d53297964b4528a16201590d0612a9:0">page and StaticQuery components</span></span></span></a><span key="1415497f03c24abfb6bc92db0d91d61a"><span offset-key="1415497f03c24abfb6bc92db0d91d61a:0"> to declare what data they and their sub-components need. Then, Gatsby makes that data available in the browser when needed by your components.</span></span>

<span key="d857a374013e4253ae559019d5306e3e"><span offset-key="d857a374013e4253ae559019d5306e3e:0">Data from any number of sources is made queryable in one unified layer, a key part of the Gatsby building process:ContentBuildDataViewAppGraphQL Response</span></span>

1

<span key="ab0ca0005ae74fb381fe06339524779a"><span offset-key="ab0ca0005ae74fb381fe06339524779a:0">data: {</span></span>

2

<span key="c17d289b080944f5b0e27fdd039d52ca"><span offset-key="c17d289b080944f5b0e27fdd039d52ca:0"> site: {</span></span>

3

<span key="b88a732631684911b7c16dc25cfb7f89"><span offset-key="b88a732631684911b7c16dc25cfb7f89:0"> title: "Home"</span></span>

4

<span key="6d0f5b2774654b68a0da7bfc1d080df2"><span offset-key="6d0f5b2774654b68a0da7bfc1d080df2:0"> description: "Gatsby tips"</span></span>

5

<span key="20fa35caa1c14b2ca8113f3bb8ff7e9f"><span offset-key="20fa35caa1c14b2ca8113f3bb8ff7e9f:0"> }</span></span>

6

<span key="23a4285f656d43f1966b02ee0d281075"><span offset-key="23a4285f656d43f1966b02ee0d281075:0">}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7" />

Copied!

<span key="a421bbb3309e4652bd3f087d0591edf8">**Data**<span offset-key="a421bbb3309e4652bd3f087d0591edf8:1"> returned by GraphQL comes back in the exact same shape that you asked for it, without having to travel across the network because it was already gathered at </span></span><a href="https://www.gatsbyjs.com/docs/glossary#build" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="0c6bdf6ab6914ebaae37538e853c06ea" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-8575_259-8576-237__"><span data-key="b1514074ca4a4cf7baa30a01ee698b5a"><span data-offset-key="b1514074ca4a4cf7baa30a01ee698b5a:0">build time</span></span></span></a><span key="5b06fdc8f3884020887f4f33c793b50b"><span offset-key="5b06fdc8f3884020887f4f33c793b50b:0">.</span></span>

<span key="68a9ae23bcb2482db85e1bdf63658bf2"><span offset-key="68a9ae23bcb2482db85e1bdf63658bf2:0">Since all data is combined in the data layer, it’s even possible to query multiple sources at the same time.</span></span>

## 

<span key="402243dacd1b4cc2adbf6c9e0ce2d6b5"><span offset-key="402243dacd1b4cc2adbf6c9e0ce2d6b5:0">Why is GraphQL so cool?</span></span>

<span key="82a5314cc5cb4e5a8b7e036e62bad216"><span offset-key="82a5314cc5cb4e5a8b7e036e62bad216:0">For a more in-depth look, read </span></span><a href="https://www.gatsbyjs.com/docs/why-gatsby-uses-graphql/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="deb85e4d9590495bba497a39a524c706" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-8575_259-8576-237__"><span data-key="69e70b601dd9455596b9108136d245c7"><span data-offset-key="69e70b601dd9455596b9108136d245c7:0">why Gatsby uses GraphQL</span></span></span></a><span key="8abb1dc6613240289139a1f9a89eca18"><span offset-key="8abb1dc6613240289139a1f9a89eca18:0">.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="246f4cb46102490e9d923d66bae2d009"><span offset-key="246f4cb46102490e9d923d66bae2d009:0">Eliminate frontend data boilerplate — no need to worry about requesting & waiting for data. Just ask for the data you need with a GraphQL query and it’ll show up when you need it</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="4fb0ff4530694bf69095847e922ad691"><span offset-key="4fb0ff4530694bf69095847e922ad691:0">Push frontend complexity into queries — many data transformations can be done at </span>*build-time*<span offset-key="4fb0ff4530694bf69095847e922ad691:2"> within your GraphQL queries</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="bafeead563184153bbfed5e6f230109b"><span offset-key="bafeead563184153bbfed5e6f230109b:0">It’s the perfect data querying language for the often complex/nested data dependencies of modern applications</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="af6045d1695f4bbcb027686841eb1400"><span offset-key="af6045d1695f4bbcb027686841eb1400:0">Improve performance by removing data bloat — GraphQL enables you to select only the data you need, not whatever an API returns</span></span>

## 

<span key="85325faf196141d897d25dd0958bd659"><span offset-key="85325faf196141d897d25dd0958bd659:0">What does a GraphQL query look like?</span></span>

<span key="6130347236cd4fd3bbc34f6f04879f31"><span offset-key="6130347236cd4fd3bbc34f6f04879f31:0">GraphQL lets you ask for the exact data you need. Queries look like JSON:</span></span>

1

<span key="68a0a7ac66104d329cab49e4e144313c"><span offset-key="68a0a7ac66104d329cab49e4e144313c:0">Copycopy code to clipboard{ site { siteMetadata { title } }}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="0c98ca68256944018e1192d96d2c341c"><span offset-key="0c98ca68256944018e1192d96d2c341c:0">Which returns this:</span></span>

1

<span key="2beab0e2f2ab470388829a3ca386d3c5"><span offset-key="2beab0e2f2ab470388829a3ca386d3c5:0">Copycopy code to clipboard{ "site": { "siteMetadata": { "title": "A Gatsby site!" } }}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="fb1ab5a6e06c4117931788979f09b5c3"><span offset-key="fb1ab5a6e06c4117931788979f09b5c3:0">A basic page component with a GraphQL query might look like this:</span></span>

1

<span key="f027d2a7f8724e4c813dfd473f1dc6b3"><span offset-key="f027d2a7f8724e4c813dfd473f1dc6b3:0">Copycopy code to clipboardimport React from "react"import { graphql } from "gatsby"export default function Page({ data }) { return ( &lt;div> &lt;h1>About {data.site.siteMetadata.title}&lt;/h1> &lt;p>We're a very cool website you should return to often.&lt;/p> &lt;/div> )}export const query = graphql\` query { site { siteMetadata { title } } }\`</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="0aae8075571048e3b6416dcae6f5b043"><span offset-key="0aae8075571048e3b6416dcae6f5b043:0">The result of the query is automatically inserted into your React component on the </span>`data`<span offset-key="0aae8075571048e3b6416dcae6f5b043:2"> prop. GraphQL and Gatsby let you ask for data and then immediately start using it.</span></span>

<span key="b3851a13f25b4e6c8d8e1482d8353ba3">**Note:**<span offset-key="b3851a13f25b4e6c8d8e1482d8353ba3:1"> To run GraphQL queries in non-page components you’ll need to use </span></span><a href="https://www.gatsbyjs.com/docs/how-to/querying-data/static-query/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="f9d8939446b74550b5157e8e613c5f61" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-8575_259-8576-237__"><span data-key="44ee44eabac64ed8bcf2b0186e77235d"><span data-offset-key="44ee44eabac64ed8bcf2b0186e77235d:0">Gatsby’s Static Query feature</span></span></span></a><span key="67d14e5cb31949e4a862031d1e0ecd5b"><span offset-key="67d14e5cb31949e4a862031d1e0ecd5b:0">.</span></span>

### 

<span key="2bdf83225ed348e4a86a78f8d01b1ec3"><span offset-key="2bdf83225ed348e4a86a78f8d01b1ec3:0">Understanding the parts of a query</span></span>

<span key="dfc29d3e13b74585b3d2d645f135b875"><span offset-key="dfc29d3e13b74585b3d2d645f135b875:0">The following diagram shows a GraphQL query, with each word highlighted in a color corresponding to its name on the legend:</span></span>

<span key="56c80cd7c9c24a63af576316b8804f25"><span offset-key="56c80cd7c9c24a63af576316b8804f25:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://www.gatsbyjs.com/static/2442c8664739d2a23483e6f16e3208a5/29007/basic-query.png" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="f30a0f1ce51a42eabb78c618227c9f78" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-8575_259-8576-237__"><span data-key="7c268dfb015b4cb58f2884296a88336e"><span data-offset-key="7c268dfb015b4cb58f2884296a88336e:0"><span data-slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><span data-slate-void="true" data-key="b3e1f7b8e13b40c4a278cfa123d81400"><span></span></span></span></a>

<span key="d23ea45b870944fa99da6f95a357a44a"><span offset-key="d23ea45b870944fa99da6f95a357a44a:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><span key="dade7f55983642ff97bcb8e7f56df59b"><span offset-key="dade7f55983642ff97bcb8e7f56df59b:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

<span key="d60a317d35f14453b64c199d0c1a436a">**Query operation type**</span>

<span key="676bbbd0533c404ca6ef9469b8fe984e"><span offset-key="676bbbd0533c404ca6ef9469b8fe984e:0">The diagram marks the word </span>`query`<span offset-key="676bbbd0533c404ca6ef9469b8fe984e:2"> as the “Operation Type”, for Gatsby’s uses the only operation type you will deal with is </span>`query`<span offset-key="676bbbd0533c404ca6ef9469b8fe984e:4">, this can be omitted from your queries if you prefer (like in the above example).</span></span>

<span key="57fe911e14cd4e20a365dae2e42d1abd">**Operation name**</span>

<span key="2b762474e41d4935930c8b42665f3e1a">`SiteInformation`<span offset-key="2b762474e41d4935930c8b42665f3e1a:1"> is marked as the “Operation Name”, which is a unique name that you assign to a query yourself. This is similar to how you would name a function or a variable, and like a function this can be omitted if you would rather the query be anonymous.</span></span>

<span key="fb19d4ca525c42bcb6f47f20f6315945">**Query fields**</span>

<span key="e8117363ad354dc395014768e80846fd"><span offset-key="e8117363ad354dc395014768e80846fd:0">The four words </span>`site`<span offset-key="e8117363ad354dc395014768e80846fd:2">, </span>`id`<span offset-key="e8117363ad354dc395014768e80846fd:4">, </span>`siteMetadata`<span offset-key="e8117363ad354dc395014768e80846fd:6">, and </span>`title`<span offset-key="e8117363ad354dc395014768e80846fd:8"> are marked as “Fields”. Any top-level fields — like </span>`site`<span offset-key="e8117363ad354dc395014768e80846fd:10"> in the diagram — are sometimes referred to as </span>**root level fields**<span offset-key="e8117363ad354dc395014768e80846fd:12">, though the name doesn’t signify functional significance as all fields in GraphQL queries behave the same.</span></span>

## 

<span key="626c625e7530401fa45d230a525cdbd1"><span offset-key="626c625e7530401fa45d230a525cdbd1:0">How to learn GraphQL</span></span>

<span key="fef3d145e1ef46368b51372e622116f1"><span offset-key="fef3d145e1ef46368b51372e622116f1:0">Your experience developing with Gatsby might be the first time you’ve seen GraphQL! We hope you love it as much as we do and find it useful for all your projects.</span></span>

<span key="ccb7a8216bad48a1802356d690913fb4"><span offset-key="ccb7a8216bad48a1802356d690913fb4:0">When starting out with GraphQL, we recommend the following two tutorials:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="96e58e4564a04d4abb98ab681072c4ee"><span offset-key="96e58e4564a04d4abb98ab681072c4ee:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://www.howtographql.com" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="95ceff17954e40519890dfb33ec1579d" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-8575_259-8576-237__"><span data-key="d4643e22521e49668aa1da6c5ecc5f56"><span data-offset-key="d4643e22521e49668aa1da6c5ecc5f56:0">https://www.howtographql.com/</span></span></span></a><span key="8bbc0995463d4f8882e8f02746daa29f"><span offset-key="8bbc0995463d4f8882e8f02746daa29f:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="64340c750ec546ce9f3fcdf27f8e1221"><span offset-key="64340c750ec546ce9f3fcdf27f8e1221:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://graphql.org/learn/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="583d1e06fae14633a86101525d3291db" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-8575_259-8576-237__"><span data-key="edd68ac3eabe46fdb726d864e7c77365"><span data-offset-key="edd68ac3eabe46fdb726d864e7c77365:0">https://graphql.org/learn/</span></span></span></a><span key="3edd7b55c970443fa149f6e459a173d8"><span offset-key="3edd7b55c970443fa149f6e459a173d8:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

<span key="7e35d5357c8a4b0a9f8983861186eb72"><span offset-key="7e35d5357c8a4b0a9f8983861186eb72:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://www.gatsbyjs.com/docs/tutorial/part-four/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="1ca3b6acb7ba48f588717506b5568034" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-8575_259-8576-237__"><span data-key="60d16c4e24e94a67b26ff7af5b0e2c34"><span data-offset-key="60d16c4e24e94a67b26ff7af5b0e2c34:0">The official Gatsby tutorial</span></span></span></a><span key="fe1074c7eb1c44f28bbf31c1d1a21f44"><span offset-key="fe1074c7eb1c44f28bbf31c1d1a21f44:0"> also includes an introduction to using GraphQL specifically with Gatsby.</span></span>

## 

<span key="efb5d236d31d401982121b870a67e91f"><span offset-key="efb5d236d31d401982121b870a67e91f:0">How do GraphQL and Gatsby work together?</span></span>

<span key="6110c537d22b4cfabe093566992e2629"><span offset-key="6110c537d22b4cfabe093566992e2629:0">One of the great things about GraphQL is how flexible it is. People use GraphQL with </span></span><a href="https://graphql.org/code/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="2aeb012b70de4c4ab08c74b1ee4d6eb9" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-8575_259-8576-237__"><span data-key="cc94ca58af6d4e17965d38371e96f752"><span data-offset-key="cc94ca58af6d4e17965d38371e96f752:0">many different programming languages</span></span></span></a><span key="659c4cdab1b24b3db6592f4dddee2eed"><span offset-key="659c4cdab1b24b3db6592f4dddee2eed:0"> and for web and native apps.</span></span>

<span key="95be7e94fc3e4849903f22c8a9b981c5"><span offset-key="95be7e94fc3e4849903f22c8a9b981c5:0">Most people run GraphQL on a server to respond live to requests for data from clients. You define a schema (a schema is a formal way of describing the shape of your data) for your GraphQL server and then your GraphQL resolvers retrieve data from databases and/or other APIs.</span></span>

<span key="ce27860f1de64503a99e246bc2cc7487"><span offset-key="ce27860f1de64503a99e246bc2cc7487:0">Gatsby uses GraphQL at </span>*build-time*<span offset-key="ce27860f1de64503a99e246bc2cc7487:2"> and </span>*not*<span offset-key="ce27860f1de64503a99e246bc2cc7487:4"> for live sites. This is unique, and it means you don’t need to run additional services (e.g. a database and Node.js service) to use GraphQL for production websites.</span></span>

<span key="83e91ed7580046be990e8118b0efef79"><span offset-key="83e91ed7580046be990e8118b0efef79:0">Gatsby is a great framework for building apps so it’s possible and encouraged to pair Gatsby’s native build-time GraphQL with GraphQL queries running against a live GraphQL server from the browser.</span></span>

## 

<span key="b7aa5b88ea2540d4bdb057d5dcf8067a"><span offset-key="b7aa5b88ea2540d4bdb057d5dcf8067a:0">Where does Gatsby’s GraphQL schema come from?</span></span>

<span key="8d183bd5510c46ca88c8c16716b6be36"><span offset-key="8d183bd5510c46ca88c8c16716b6be36:0">Most usages of GraphQL involve manually creating a GraphQL schema.</span></span>

<span key="5173b3a6bb7e4bb8b6639cbe2efca583"><span offset-key="5173b3a6bb7e4bb8b6639cbe2efca583:0">Gatsby uses plugins which can fetch data from different sources. That data is used to automatically </span>*infer*<span offset-key="5173b3a6bb7e4bb8b6639cbe2efca583:2"> a GraphQL schema.</span></span>

<span key="9bd05793777f43e3b84a12b4ddad2d6d"><span offset-key="9bd05793777f43e3b84a12b4ddad2d6d:0">If you give Gatsby data that looks like this:</span></span>

1

<span key="281d19881ca343d48238a3673aa7501b"><span offset-key="281d19881ca343d48238a3673aa7501b:0">Copycopy code to clipboard{ "title": "A long long time ago"}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="38597d762ce24bbf9c4f01db1af7ab26"><span offset-key="38597d762ce24bbf9c4f01db1af7ab26:0">Gatsby will create a schema that looks something like this:</span></span>

1

<span key="0c0d27a4ce2e4d35847c42452f5ccc4c"><span offset-key="0c0d27a4ce2e4d35847c42452f5ccc4c:0">Copycopy code to clipboardtitle: String</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="839eb3131a814f668a1bcfdf028e3ea7"><span offset-key="839eb3131a814f668a1bcfdf028e3ea7:0">This makes it possible to pull data from anywhere and immediately start writing GraphQL queries against your data.</span></span>

<span key="589e88b4952f4fc7a57675eb1d46fdf2"><span offset-key="589e88b4952f4fc7a57675eb1d46fdf2:0">This </span>*can*<span offset-key="589e88b4952f4fc7a57675eb1d46fdf2:2"> cause confusion as some data sources allow you to define a schema even when there’s not any data added for parts or all of the schema. If parts of the data haven’t been added, then those parts of the schema might not be recreated in Gatsby.</span></span>

## 

<span key="47bc29ac0efc49fcaa43853a78e09184"><span offset-key="47bc29ac0efc49fcaa43853a78e09184:0">Powerful data transformations</span></span>

<span key="fe7fd2cc5d5c4f769f72cd872007f518"><span offset-key="fe7fd2cc5d5c4f769f72cd872007f518:0">GraphQL enables another unique feature of Gatsby — it lets you control data transformations with arguments to your queries. Some examples follow.</span></span>

### 

<span key="d5abab178771405bbd8e017fbd187023"><span offset-key="d5abab178771405bbd8e017fbd187023:0">Formatting dates</span></span>

<span key="90ed2e9df0e14304bf7d2955ca64bfa1"><span offset-key="90ed2e9df0e14304bf7d2955ca64bfa1:0">People often store dates like “2018-01-05” but want to display the date in some other form like “January 5th, 2018”. One way of doing this is to load a date-formatting JavaScript library into the browser. Or, with Gatsby’s GraphQL layer, you can do the formatting at query-time like:</span></span>

1

<span key="92dd35b458f04cab9a2084f2afd3b178"><span offset-key="92dd35b458f04cab9a2084f2afd3b178:0">Copycopy code to clipboard{ date(formatString: "MMMM Do, YYYY")}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="246e8bd414f54c8d94d3d2e299c14125"><span offset-key="246e8bd414f54c8d94d3d2e299c14125:0">See the full list of formatting options by viewing our </span></span><a href="https://www.gatsbyjs.com/docs/graphql-reference/#dates" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="ffe2589a91334c1cb0b6abe054b71071" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-8575_259-8576-237__"><span data-key="a681235bf28e4600a68cb95110bd3c8c"><span data-offset-key="a681235bf28e4600a68cb95110bd3c8c:0">GraphQL reference page</span></span></span></a><span key="84dc2ecf29394665abe73932a87edcb2"><span offset-key="84dc2ecf29394665abe73932a87edcb2:0">.</span></span>

### 

<span key="c47e7a1b5aca432c9ee30ecf0ff4390a"><span offset-key="c47e7a1b5aca432c9ee30ecf0ff4390a:0">Markdown</span></span>

<span key="b14174ce3f334276ac56bf5acfe11fbf"><span offset-key="b14174ce3f334276ac56bf5acfe11fbf:0">Gatsby has </span>*transformer*<span offset-key="b14174ce3f334276ac56bf5acfe11fbf:2"> plugins which can transform data from one form to another. A common example is markdown. If you install </span></span><a href="https://www.gatsbyjs.com/plugins/gatsby-transformer-remark/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="133012c9c3844a4e86f590bda385df1d" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-8575_259-8576-237__"><span data-key="f05114b557a4446b8e2141afa0924a61"><code class="r-1vckr1u r-z2wwpe r-uibjmv r-m2pi6t r-1hvjb8t" data-slate-leaf="true" data-offset-key="f05114b557a4446b8e2141afa0924a61:0">gatsby-transformer-remark</code></span></span></a><span key="5b13a1b6e8194622a2f9b65e456b1d0d"><span offset-key="5b13a1b6e8194622a2f9b65e456b1d0d:0">, then in your queries, you can specify if you want the transformed HTML version instead of markdown:</span></span>

1

<span key="801bf4b9b11441eba0dcfd2e1bccacf4"><span offset-key="801bf4b9b11441eba0dcfd2e1bccacf4:0">Copycopy code to clipboardmarkdownRemark { html}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

### 

<span key="fed67d80f2c54f80973d833c95e28ee7"><span offset-key="fed67d80f2c54f80973d833c95e28ee7:0">Images</span></span>

<span key="06c9d7f7b8d54195b9dffe6d5ab8556a"><span offset-key="06c9d7f7b8d54195b9dffe6d5ab8556a:0">Gatsby has rich support for processing images. Responsive images are a big part of the modern web and typically involve creating 5+ sized thumbnails per photo. With Gatsby’s </span></span><a href="https://www.gatsbyjs.com/plugins/gatsby-transformer-sharp/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="3d6f286279dd41f6b89c601f35d3a6ac" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-8575_259-8576-237__"><span data-key="11df5bd0170f40a68801c032021a9929"><code class="r-1vckr1u r-z2wwpe r-uibjmv r-m2pi6t r-1hvjb8t" data-slate-leaf="true" data-offset-key="11df5bd0170f40a68801c032021a9929:0">gatsby-transformer-sharp</code></span></span></a><span key="0468d6e1a77d454eb8c9df97dc6c3f03"><span offset-key="0468d6e1a77d454eb8c9df97dc6c3f03:0">, you can </span>*query*<span offset-key="0468d6e1a77d454eb8c9df97dc6c3f03:2"> your images for responsive versions. The query automatically creates all the needed responsive thumbnails and returns </span>`src`<span offset-key="0468d6e1a77d454eb8c9df97dc6c3f03:4"> and </span>`srcSet`<span offset-key="0468d6e1a77d454eb8c9df97dc6c3f03:6"> fields to add to your image element.</span></span>

<span key="c158a61cf5c44a189527f0f8fd9803b1"><span offset-key="c158a61cf5c44a189527f0f8fd9803b1:0">Combined with a special Gatsby image component, </span></span><a href="https://www.gatsbyjs.com/plugins/gatsby-image/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="3c6aaec9537e4dc19efa95b4560c74b5" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-8575_259-8576-237__"><span data-key="6a90e3964d7f4df1ad2f245d78991689"><span data-offset-key="6a90e3964d7f4df1ad2f245d78991689:0">gatsby-image</span></span></span></a><span key="a42c148bd12342bc897d191807b77532"><span offset-key="a42c148bd12342bc897d191807b77532:0">, you have a very powerful set of primitives for building sites with images.</span></span>

<span key="c6e4f2414f5741b693102f08072c1f8d"><span offset-key="c6e4f2414f5741b693102f08072c1f8d:0">This is what a component using </span>`gatsby-image`<span offset-key="c6e4f2414f5741b693102f08072c1f8d:2"> looks like:</span></span>

1

<span key="0796e0c8714a4cfba981cbae607580ca"><span offset-key="0796e0c8714a4cfba981cbae607580ca:0">Copycopy code to clipboardimport React from "react"import Img from "gatsby-image"import { graphql } from "gatsby"export default function Page({ data }) { return ( &lt;div> &lt;h1>Hello gatsby-image&lt;/h1> &lt;Img fixed={data.file.childImageSharp.fixed} /> &lt;/div> )}export const query = graphql\` query { file(relativePath: { eq: "blog/avatars/kyle-mathews.jpeg" }) { childImageSharp { # Specify the image processing specifications right in the query. # Makes it trivial to update as your page's design changes. fixed(width: 125, height: 125) { ...GatsbyImageSharpFixed } } } }\`</span></span>

## 

<span key="d84387ecc7a04028937edc162896feca"><span offset-key="d84387ecc7a04028937edc162896feca:0">Advanced</span></span>

### 

<span key="47d5e88b407e441e866a0cefc0064d50"><span offset-key="47d5e88b407e441e866a0cefc0064d50:0">Fragments</span></span>

<span key="13c9dde438e9437688a3a74b14a5d2ab"><span offset-key="13c9dde438e9437688a3a74b14a5d2ab:0">Notice that in the above example for </span></span><a href="https://www.gatsbyjs.com/docs/conceptual/graphql-concepts/#images" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="be4057aaf80841349ab1aa912f02537b" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-8575_259-8576-237__"><span data-key="e2b7beea9839466f91863a0a5a82500c"><span data-offset-key="e2b7beea9839466f91863a0a5a82500c:0">querying images</span></span></span></a><span key="94e6b61da86b44bc879d07d584c0adf6"><span offset-key="94e6b61da86b44bc879d07d584c0adf6:0">, we used </span>`...GatsbyImageSharpFixed`<span offset-key="94e6b61da86b44bc879d07d584c0adf6:2">, which is a GraphQL Fragment, a reusable set of fields for query composition. You can read more about them </span></span><a href="https://graphql.org/learn/queries/#fragments" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="7132ebf8eb874d77aa2ace930cd66828" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-8575_259-8576-237__"><span data-key="98ea8b0e2d6845778250d80e6e66ea47"><span data-offset-key="98ea8b0e2d6845778250d80e6e66ea47:0">here</span></span></span></a><span key="49fd38297d724f7cb84c8dba39180f65"><span offset-key="49fd38297d724f7cb84c8dba39180f65:0">.</span></span>

<span key="20e359a97b224b6fb9a4ef1a808e9920"><span offset-key="20e359a97b224b6fb9a4ef1a808e9920:0">If you wish to define your own fragments for use in your application, you can use named exports to export them in any JavaScript file, and they will be automatically processed by Gatsby for use in your GraphQL queries.</span></span>

<span key="c1b7d8fd12da4b49a8d37b211b8ff805"><span offset-key="c1b7d8fd12da4b49a8d37b211b8ff805:0">For example, if I put a fragment in a helper component, I can use that fragment in any other query:src/components/PostItem.js</span></span>

1

<span key="190b4b83baa64ce1a94f6191eb704204"><span offset-key="190b4b83baa64ce1a94f6191eb704204:0">Copysrc/components/PostItem.js: copy code to clipboardexport const markdownFrontmatterFragment = graphql\` fragment MarkdownFrontmatter on MarkdownRemark { frontmatter { path title date(formatString: "MMMM DD, YYYY") } }\`</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="5b63d084303b4031ba09e6613ff6fdea"><span offset-key="5b63d084303b4031ba09e6613ff6fdea:0">They can then be used in any GraphQL query after that!</span></span>

1

<span key="f632059c3e5e4498a719e3d368f5fb49"><span offset-key="f632059c3e5e4498a719e3d368f5fb49:0">Copycopy code to clipboardquery ($path: String!) { markdownRemark(frontmatter: { path: { eq: $path } }) { ...MarkdownFrontmatter }}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="f94e6c6fc0be4540b46a9482417262e0"><span offset-key="f94e6c6fc0be4540b46a9482417262e0:0">It’s good practice for your helper components to define and export a fragment for the data they need. For example, on your index page you might map over all of your posts to show them in a list.src/pages/index.jsx</span></span>

1

<span key="d0f083f9d7a74485a4c1af96c61553ed"><span offset-key="d0f083f9d7a74485a4c1af96c61553ed:0">Copysrc/pages/index.jsx: copy code to clipboardimport React from "react"import { graphql } from "gatsby"export default function Home({ data }) { return ( &lt;div> &lt;h1>Index page&lt;/h1> &lt;h4>{data.allMarkdownRemark.totalCount} Posts&lt;/h4> {data.allMarkdownRemark.edges.map(({ node }) => ( &lt;div key={node.id}> &lt;h3> {node.frontmatter.title} &lt;span>— {node.frontmatter.date}&lt;/span> &lt;/h3> &lt;/div> ))} &lt;/div> )}export const query = graphql\` query { allMarkdownRemark { totalCount edges { node { id frontmatter { title date(formatString: "DD MMMM, YYYY") } } } } }\`</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="ecbbcfab7bed41b9a0c95ed6ee3a2c13"><span offset-key="ecbbcfab7bed41b9a0c95ed6ee3a2c13:0">If the index component becomes too large, you might want to refactor it into smaller components.src/components/IndexPost.jsx</span></span>

1

<span key="378ff72bad65465c8faea2c09650e97a"><span offset-key="378ff72bad65465c8faea2c09650e97a:0">Copysrc/components/IndexPost.jsx: copy code to clipboardimport React from "react"import { graphql } from "gatsby"export default function IndexPost({ frontmatter: { title, date } }) { return ( &lt;div> &lt;h3> {title} &lt;span>— {date}&lt;/span> &lt;/h3> &lt;/div> )}export const query = graphql\` fragment IndexPostFragment on MarkdownRemark { frontmatter { title date(formatString: "MMMM DD, YYYY") } }\`</span></span>

<span key="5c26d7a02a4b4e41b20f483a4063a186"><span offset-key="5c26d7a02a4b4e41b20f483a4063a186:0">Now, you can use the component together with the exported fragment in your index page.src/pages/index.jsx</span></span>

1

<span key="46d1b0a2ca5f4679b445e6f5560f683b"><span offset-key="46d1b0a2ca5f4679b445e6f5560f683b:0">Copysrc/pages/index.jsx: copy code to clipboardimport React from "react"import IndexPost from "../components/IndexPost"import { graphql } from "gatsby"export default function Home({ data }) { return ( &lt;div> &lt;h1>Index page&lt;/h1> &lt;h4>{data.allMarkdownRemark.totalCount} Posts&lt;/h4> {data.allMarkdownRemark.edges.map(({ node }) => ( &lt;div key={node.id}> &lt;IndexPost frontmatter={node.frontmatter} /> &lt;/div> ))} &lt;/div> )}export const query = graphql\` query { allMarkdownRemark { totalCount edges { node { id ...IndexPostFragment } } } }\`</span></span>

    <span key="36603423c93c4d00b2343fa34c6897ba"><span offset-key="36603423c93c4d00b2343fa34c6897ba:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://services.github.com/on-demand/graphql/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="bbd211c8141044f390ecfdc6235d7508" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-8575_259-8576-237__"><span data-key="01ab85cbe5074f088b10ff02bcdad627"><span data-offset-key="01ab85cbe5074f088b10ff02bcdad627:0">https://services.github.com/on-demand/graphql/</span></span></span></a><span key="288fcefd8b284edd914d500433554d13"><span offset-key="288fcefd8b284edd914d500433554d13:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>
